What are some of the key features and updates in Verus Desktop v0.9.5, and how do they enhance the Verus ecosystem, particularly in terms of digital signing, verification, and DeFi protocols?

Verus Desktop v0.9.5 is an update to the Verus Desktop wallet that introduces several new features and enhancements to the Verus ecosystem. One of the key updates is the introduction of two new APIs and CLI commands, `signdata` and `verifysignature`, which provide a more powerful and flexible framework for digital signing and verification.

These new APIs enable users to bind together multiple sources of content, documents, identities, and VDXF keys into one verifiable signature. This allows for advanced signatures and verification capabilities, making it ideal for use cases such as NFTs and ID-bound legal rights and agreements.

In addition to digital signing and verification, Verus Desktop v0.9.5 also updates the Komodo notaries to season 6, which is essential for reliably staying synchronized to the Verus mainnet.

Furthermore, the Verus ecosystem is also seeing updates to its PBaaS and DeFi protocols. Community developers have introduced a protocol improvement designed to make the Verus anti-MEV DeFi protocol even more resistant to multi-block attempts at MEV (Maximum Extractable Value). This improvement makes adjustments to conversions and cross-chain transfers, which now roll-up into exports that are collected from one or more blocks.

Overall, these updates and features enhance the Verus ecosystem by providing more advanced and flexible capabilities for digital signing and verification, as well as improving the security and resistance of the DeFi protocol.

Verus Desktop v0.9.5 Update
⏰ Update your Verus Desktop wallet before 19 November 11 PM UTC. This release updates the Komodo notaries to season 6 and you must update to reliably stay synchronized to the Verus mainnet (activation height of block 2,291,830).
v0.9.5 introduces 2 new APIs and CLI commands, signdata and verifysignature, that encompass all of the capabilities of previous signing and verification APIs and add new capabilities for advanced signatures and verification — a more powerful and flexible framework for NFTs and ID-bound legal rights and agreements.
In addition to digital signing of documents or information using an ID, the new APIs enable easily binding together multiple sources of content, documents, identities, and VDXF keys together into one verifiable signature and then being able to verify that signature, including all of its specific bindings.
